inlineContent.text: is the base class all widgets in GTK derive from. It manages the
widget lifecycle, layout, states and style.
GTK uses a height-for-width (and width-for-height) geometry management
system. Height-for-width means that a widget can change how much
vertical space it needs, depending on the amount of horizontal space
that it is given (and similar for width-for-height). The most common
example is a label that reflows to fill up the available width, wraps
to fewer lines, and therefore needs less height.
Height-for-width geometry management is implemented in GTK by way
of two virtual methods:
[vfunc
[vfunc
There are some important things to keep in mind when implementing
height-for-width and when using it in widget implementations.
If you implement a direct
subclass that supports
height-for-width or width-for-height geometry management for itself
or its child widgets, the [vfunc
] virtual
function must be implemented as well and return the widget’s preferred
request mode. The default implementation of this virtual function
returns
, which means that the widget will
only ever get -1 passed as the for_size value to its
[vfunc
] implementation.
The geometry management system will query a widget hierarchy in
only one orientation at a time. When widgets are initially queried
for their minimum sizes it is generally done in two initial passes
in the [enum
] chosen by the toplevel.
For example, when queried in the normal
mode:
First, the default minimum and natural width for each widget
in the interface will be computed using [id
] with an
orientation of
and a for_size of -1.
Because the preferred widths for each widget depend on the preferred
widths of their children, this information propagates up the hierarchy,
and finally a minimum and natural width is determined for the entire
toplevel. Next, the toplevel will use the minimum width to query for the
minimum height contextual to that width using [id
] with an
orientation of
and a for_size of the just computed
width. This will also be a highly recursive operation. The minimum height
for the minimum width is normally used to set the minimum size constraint
on the toplevel.
After the toplevel window has initially requested its size in both
dimensions it can go on to allocate itself a reasonable size (or a size
previously specified with [method
]). During the
recursive allocation process it’s important to note that request cycles
will be recursively executed while widgets allocate their children.
Each widget, once allocated a size, will go on to first share the
space in one orientation among its children and then request each child’s
height for its target allocated width or its width for allocated height,
depending. In this way a
will typically be requested its size
a number of times before actually being allocated a size. The size a
widget is finally allocated can of course differ from the size it has
requested. For this reason,
caches a  small number of results
to avoid re-querying for the same sizes in one allocation cycle.
If a widget does move content around to intelligently use up the
allocated size then it must support the request in both
s even if the widget in question only
trades sizes in a single orientation.
For instance, a [class
] that does height-for-width word wrapping
will not expect to have [vfunc
] with an orientation of
called because that call is specific to a
width-for-height request. In this case the label must return the height
required for its own minimum possible width. By following this rule any
widget that handles height-for-width or width-for-height requests will
always be allocated at least enough space to fit its own content.
Here are some examples of how a
widget
generally deals with width-for-height requests:

code: // First, get the minimum width of our widget
// Now use the minimum width to retrieve the minimum and natural height to display

inlineContent.text: Often a widget needs to get its own request during size request or
allocation. For example, when computing height it may need to also
compute width. Or when deciding how to use an allocation, the widget
may need to know its natural size. In these cases, the widget should
be careful to call its virtual methods directly, like in the code
example above.
It will not work to use the wrapper function [method
inside your own [vfunc
] implementation.
These return a request adjusted by [class
], the widget’s
align and expand flags, as well as its CSS style.
If a widget used the wrappers inside its virtual method implementations,
then the adjustments (such as widget margins) would be applied
twice. GTK therefore does not allow this and will warn if you try
to do it.
Of course if you are getting the size request for another widget, such
as a child widget, you must use [id
]; otherwise, you
would not properly consider widget margins, [class
], and
so forth.
GTK also supports baseline vertical alignment of widgets. This
means that widgets are positioned such that the typographical baseline of
widgets in the same row are aligned. This happens if a widget supports
baselines, has a vertical alignment using baselines, and is inside
a widget that supports baselines and has a natural “row” that it aligns to
the baseline, or a baseline assigned to it by the grandparent.
Baseline alignment support for a widget is also done by the
[vfunc
] virtual function. It allows you to report
both a minimum and natural size.
If a widget ends up baseline aligned it will be allocated all the space in
the parent as if it was
, but the selected baseline can be
found via [id
]. If the baseline has a
value other than -1 you need to align the widget such that the baseline
appears at the position.
The
implementation of the
interface
supports various custom elements to specify additional aspects of widgets
that are not directly expressed as properties.
If the widget uses a [class
supports
a custom
element, used to define layout properties:
allows style information such as style classes to
be associated with widgets, using the custom
element:
allows defining accessibility information, such as properties,
relations, and states, using the custom
element:

content.text: Building composite widgets from template XML

inlineContent.text: exposes some facilities to automate the procedure
of creating composite widgets using “templates”.
To create composite widgets with
XML, one must associate
the interface description with the widget class at class initialization
time using [method
The interface description semantics expected in composite template descriptions
is slightly different from regular [class
] XML.
Unlike regular interface descriptions, [method
will expect a
tag as a direct child of the toplevel
tag. The
tag must specify the “class” attribute
which must be the type name of the widget. Optionally, the “parent”
attribute may be specified to specify the direct parent type of the widget
type; this is ignored by
but can be used by UI design tools to
introspect what kind of properties and internal children exist for a given
type when the actual type does not exist.
The XML which is contained inside the
tag behaves as if it were
added to the
tag defining the widget itself. You may set properties
on a widget by inserting
tags into the
tag, and also
add
tags to add children and extend a widget in the normal way you
would with
tags.
Additionally,
tags can also be added before and after the initial
tag in the normal way, allowing one to define auxiliary objects
which might be referenced by other widgets declared as children of the
tag.
An example of a template definition:
Typically, you’ll place the template fragment into a file that is
bundled with your project, using
. In order to load the
template, you need to call [method
from the class initialization of your
type:
You will also need to call [method
] from the
instance initialization function:

code: // Initialize the rest of the widget...

inlineContent.text: as well as calling [method
] from the dispose
function:

code: // Dispose objects for which you have a reference...
// Clear the template children for this widget type

inlineContent.text: You can access widgets defined in the template using the
[id
] function, but you will typically declare
a pointer in the instance private data structure of your type using the same
name as the widget in the template definition, and call
[method
] (or one of its wrapper macros
[func
] and [func
with that name, e.g.
You can also use [method
] (or
is wrapper macro [func
]) to connect
a signal callback defined in the template with a function visible in the
scope of the class, e.g.

code: // the signal handler has the instance and user data swapped
// because of the swapped="yes" attribute in the template XML

inlineContent.text: The
protocol exposes the methods and properties of an underlying
instance.
The default implementation of these can be found in the protocol extension below.
For a concrete class that implements these methods and properties, see
Alternatively, use
as a lighweight,
reference if you already have an instance you just want to use.
